'''Whole body vibration''' ('''WBV''') is a generic term used when vibrations (mechanical oscillations) of any frequency are transferred to the human body. Humans are exposed to vibration through a contact surface that is in a mechanical vibrating state. Human's are generally exposed to many different forms of vibration in their daily lives. This could be a driver's seat, a moving train platform, through a power tool, a training platform, or one of countless other devices.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/human-response-to-vibration/oclc/55681295|title=Human response to vibration|last=Mansfield|first=Neil J|date=2005|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0415282390|location=Boca Raton, FL}}</ref> It is a potential form of [[occupational hazard]], particularly after years of exposure.
When high frequency vibrations<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pyykkö I, Färkkilä M, Toivanen J, Korhonen O, Hyvärinen J | title = Transmission of vibration in the hand-arm system with special reference to changes in compression force and acceleration | journal = Scandinavian Journal of Work, Environment & Health | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 87–95 | date = June 1976 | pmid = 959789 | jstor = 40964583 }}</ref> (above 50 Hz) enter though the hands, [[Vibration white finger|occupational safety]] concerns may arise. For example, when working with a [[jackhammer]] and the development of [[vibration white finger]]. Exposures and limits have been estimated in the ISO 5349-1 for hand-transmitted vibration.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/ISO-5349-1-Measurement-hand-transmitted-requirements/dp/B000XYSRXU|title=ISO 5349-1:2001, Mechanical vibration – Measurement and evaluation of human exposure to hand-transmitted vibration – Part 1: General requirements | authors =ISO TC 108/SC 4/WG3|date=2007-08-23|publisher=Multiple. Distributed through American National Standards Institute }}</ref>
Whole body '''vibration training''' as a form of [[physical exercise]] can offer some fitness and health benefits, but it is not clear if it is as beneficial as regular physical exercise.<ref name="mayo">{{cite web|url=https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/fitness/expert-answers/whole-body-vibration/faq-20057958|title=Is whole-body vibration a good way to lose weight and improve fitness?| first = Edward R. | last = Laskowski | name-list-format = vanc | website = [[Mayo Clinic]] |access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> A review in 2014 came to the conclusion that there is little and inconsistent evidence that acute and/or chronic whole body vibration could improve the performance of competitive and/or elite athletes.<ref name="eurjhm">{{cite journal|url=http://www.eurjhm.com/index.php/eurjhm/article/view/339|title=Whole body vibration and athletic performance: A scoping review|author=Tibor Hortobágyi, Urs Granacher, Miguel Fernandez-del-Olmo|journal=European Journal of Human Movement|volume=33|year=2014}}</ref>
== As a hazard == Humans are sensitive to mechanical oscillations ranging in frequency from well below 1 Hz up to 100 Hz.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1971-03-08|title=Human sensitivity to vibration|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0022460X71903543|journal=Journal of Sound and Vibration|volume=15|issue=1|pages=11–16|doi=10.1016/0022-460X(71)90354-3|issn=0022-460X|last1=Guignard|first1=J.C.}}</ref> Lower frequencies of vibration lead to human motion sickness<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Lawther A, Griffin MJ|date=September 1987|title=Prediction of the incidence of motion sickness from the magnitude, frequency, and duration of vertical oscillation|journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America|volume=82|issue=3|pages=957–66|pmid=3655126}}</ref> while higher frequencies can lead to general annoyance and discomfort. The minimization of discomfort due to vehicle vibration is important in the automotive industry where ride quality is important. Discomfort and even pain may extremely prevalent in situations where medically injured patients are transported. The discomfort due to vibration can estimated in various environments.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=DeShaw J, Rahmatalla S|date=April 2016|title=Predictive discomfort of supine humans in whole-body vibration and shock environments|journal=Ergonomics|volume=59|issue=4|pages=568–81|doi=10.1080/00140139.2015.1083125|pmid=26280381}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=DeShaw J, Rahmatalla S|date=August 2014|title=Predictive discomfort in single- and combined-axis whole-body vibration considering different seated postures|journal=Human Factors|volume=56|issue=5|pages=850–63|doi=10.1177/0018720813516993|pmid=25141593}}</ref>
===Workplace exposure=== [[File:Lateral X-ray of lumbar spine spondylosis.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Projectional radiography|X-ray]] of [[spondylosis]] of the [[lumbar spine]].]] [[Occupational safety and health|Workplace exposures]] to whole-body vibrations for long durations can lead to [[Human musculoskeletal system|musculoskeletal]] problems of many kinds.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Magnusson ML, Pope MH, Wilder DG, Areskoug B | title = Are occupational drivers at an increased risk for developing musculoskeletal disorders? | journal = Spine | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 710–7 | date = March 1996 | pmid = 8882693 }}</ref> Problems of the neck and lower back in particular can be common for operators of heavy equipment including construction, forestry, agriculture, and trucking. Other occupations where whole-body vibrations may be present include operatorsof aircraft, workers on-board sea vessels, drivers of public transportation including trains and buses among others.
Farmers with long-term exposure to whole body vibration and mechanical shocks have a higher prevalence of [[back pain]] (compared to those not exposed to vibration), and the prevalence increases with vibration dose.<ref name="Solecki">{{cite journal | vauthors = Solecki L | title = [Low back pain among farmers exposed to whole body vibration: a literature review] | journal = Medycyna Pracy | volume = 62 | issue = 2 | pages = 187–202 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21698878 | pmc = | doi = | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/eutils/elink.fcgi?dbfrom=pubmed&tool=sumsearch.org/cite&retmode=ref&cmd=prlinks&id=21698878 }}</ref> Long-term exposure affecting the whole body leads to spinal degeneration ([[spondylosis]]) and increased risk of low back pain.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pope MH, Wilder DG, Magnusson ML | title = A review of studies on seated whole body vibration and low back pain | journal = Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine | volume = 213 | issue = 6 | pages = 435–46 | date = 1999 | pmid = 10635692 | doi = 10.1243/0954411991535040 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wilder DG, Pope MH | title = Epidemiological and aetiological aspects of low back pain in vibration environments - an update | journal = Clinical Biomechanics | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 61–73 | date = March 1996 | pmid = 11415601 }}</ref>
Factors that affect the occupational exposure to whole-body vibration include the frequency of vibrations, the magnitude of vibrations, the daily exposure to vibrations, the standing or seating posture of the operator, the direction of the vibration, and how tightly coupled the human is to the source of the vibration.<ref name = "Griffin_1990">{{Cite book|title=Handbook of human vibration | vauthors = Griffin MJ | date=1990|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=9780123030405|location=London|oclc=21591126}}</ref> Exposure limits and estimates have been characterized in the ISO 2631-1<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iso.org/standard/7612.html|title=ISO 2631-1:1997 - Mechanical vibration and shock – Evaluation of human exposure to whole-body vibration – Part 1: General requirements|website=www.iso.org|access-date=2018-05-24}}</ref> for whole-body vibration. Measurements of vibration exposure are usually taken at the human/vibration interface.
=== Patient transport === Injured patients can be exposed to shocks and vibrations during transport which can worsen patient conditions due to involuntary motions of the body. Many forms of immobilization devices are used to limit this motion with varying degrees of success.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mahshidfar B, Mofidi M, Yari AR, Mehrsorosh S | title = Long backboard versus vacuum mattress splint to immobilize whole spine in trauma victims in the field: a randomized clinical trial | journal = Prehospital and Disaster Medicine | volume = 28 | issue = 5 | pages = 462–5 | date = October 2013 | pmid = 23746392 | doi = 10.1017/S1049023X13008637 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Rahmatalla S, DeShaw J, Stilley J, Denning G, Jennissen C | title = Comparing the Efficacy of Methods for Immobilizing the Thoracic-Lumbar Spine | journal = Air Medical Journal | volume = 37 | issue = 3 | pages = 178–185 | date = May 2018 | pmid = 29735231 | doi = 10.1016/j.amj.2018.02.002 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sundstrøm T, Asbjørnsen H, Habiba S, Sunde GA, Wester K | title = Prehospital use of cervical collars in trauma patients: a critical review | journal = Journal of Neurotrauma | volume = 31 | issue = 6 | pages = 531–40 | date = March 2014 | pmid = 23962031 | pmc = 3949434 | doi = 10.1089/neu.2013.3094 }}</ref> Common modes of patient transport include hand carried stretcher ([[Litter (rescue basket)|litter]]), ground [[ambulance]], and [[air medical services]] which all contain multiple forms of shocks and whole-body vibrations.
=== Measurement === Measurements are taken with accelerometers to estimate the amount of vibration exposure to the human body. These measurements are taken at the human body or at the vibration source or surface.<ref name = "Griffin_1990" /> Measurements of different directions are taken to relate the motion direction with the response of the human body.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://search.proquest.com/openview/9122b728e987f0b6da45e4586c98772e/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750&diss=y|title=New methodologies for evaluating human biodynamic response and discomfort during seated whole-body vibration considering multiple postures - ProQuest|website=search.proquest.com|access-date=2018-05-31}}</ref> Specifically, transfer functions can be used to determine the human response to the vibration.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hinz B, Menzel G, Blüthner R, Seidel H | title = Seat-to-head transfer function of seated men--determination with single and three axis excitations at different magnitudes | journal = Industrial Health | volume = 48 | issue = 5 | pages = 565–83 | date = 2010 | pmid = 20953074 | doi = 10.2486/indhealth.MSWBVI-03 | url = https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/indhealth/48/5/48_MSWBVI-03/_article/-char/en }}</ref> Measurement techniques for estimating exposures to whole body vibrations and hand-arm vibration have been developed in International Standards.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.iso.org/standard/70648.html | title=ISO 8041-1:2017 - Human response to vibration – Measuring instrumentation – Part 1: General purpose vibration meters|website=www.iso.org }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/ISO-5349-2-Measurement-hand-transmitted-measurement/dp/B000Y2T50A/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1526962106&sr=1-1&keywords=ISO+5349-2|title=ISO 5349-2:2001, Mechanical vibration - Measurement and evaluation of human exposure to hand-transmitted vibration - Part 2: Practical guidance for measurement at the workplace| author = ISO/TC 108/SC4|date=2007-08-23|publisher=Multiple. Distributed through American National Standards Institute}}</ref>
==Vibration training== Vibration training is the deliberate exposure to the body of varying frequencies/amplitudes/forces using certain joint angles for any limited time (approximately 1 minute sets). It is also known as '''vibration therapy''','''vibrotherapy''', '''biomechanical stimulation''' ('''BMS'''), '''mechanostimulation''' and '''biomechanical oscillation''' ('''BMO'''). It employs low amplitude, low frequency mechanical stimulation. It can be pivotal/oscillating (vibrating from side to side) or lineal (vibrating up and down).
===History===
The immediate predecessor of modern vibration training is Rhythmic Neuromuscular Stimulation (RNS). In former [[East Germany]] Biermann was experimenting with the use of cyclic massage and its effects on trunk flexion back in the sixties (''Biermann, 1960''<ref name="biermann60">{{Cite journal|last1=Biermann|first1=W.|title=Influence of cycloid vibration massage on trunk flexion|url=|journal=American Journal of Physical Medicine|volume=1960|issue=39|pages=219–224}}</ref>).
The technique has been tested on turkeys in the hope of finding a benefit that could be used for astronauts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://science1.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2001/ast02nov_1/|title=Good Vibrations}}</ref> For the used technology an engineering issues came into play when they tried to upgrade the machine to take the weight of a human being. Once the vibration intensity grew strong enough to lift over 40 kg, fractures appeared in the steel. Using a different mechnanical stimulation approach the first bedrest study using a vibration training device for humans was done by the European Space Agency (ESA) in 2003 in Berlin<ref>Rittweger J., Felsenberg D.: ''Resistive vibration exercise prevents bone loss during 8 weeks of strict bed rest in healthy male subjects: results from the Berlin Bed Rest (BBR) study'', 26th Annual Meeting of the American Society for Bone and Mineral Research; October 2004; Seattle</ref> (Berlin Bedrest Study, BBR). The same technology was then used in several parabolic flight campaigns of the DLR (German Aerospace Agency) starting in 2006 where the feasibility of use of a lightweight vibration training device under microgravity conditions was demonstrated and ein 2009 and 2010 where basic research on influence of microgravity on vibration training effects was investigated.<ref name="Kramer13">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kramer A, Gollhofer A, Ritzmann R | title = Acute exposure to microgravity does not influence the H-reflex with or without whole body vibration and does not cause vibration-specific changes in muscular activity | journal = Journal of Electromyography and Kinesiology | volume = 23 | issue = 4 | pages = 872–8 | date = August 2013 | pmid = 23541330 | doi = 10.1016/j.jelekin.2013.02.010 }}</ref><ref name="Ritzmann,16">{{cite journal|vauthors=Ritzmann R, Krause A, Freyler K, Gollhofer A|year=2016|title=Gravity and Neuronal Adaptation - Neurophysiology of Reflexes from Hypo- to Hypergravity Conditions|journal=Microgravity Sci. Technol.}}</ref>
NASA, since 1961, has been doing tests at adding light vibrations to pre-existing exercise equipment’s and systems to minimize vibration transmission of existing exercise devices to the space station like the Treadmill Vibration Isolation System (TVIS) and the Cycle Ergometer Vibration Isolation System (CEVIS). Any company referencing NASA directly in its marketing campaigns is highly misleading and has no relevance to the discipline of vibration training.
The first Galileo machine patent was filed in 1996 in the same year the first Galileo device was commercially available.<ref name="Bosco99b">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bosco C, Colli R, Introini E, Cardinale M, Tsarpela O, Madella A, Tihanyi J, Viru A | title = Adaptive responses of human skeletal muscle to vibration exposure | journal = Clinical Physiology | volume = 19 | issue = 2 | pages = 183–7 | date = March 1999 | pmid = 10200901 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-2281.1999.00155.x }}</ref><ref name="Bosco98c">{{cite journal|vauthors=Bosco C, Cardinale M, Tsarpela O, Colli R, Tihanyi J, Ducillard C, Viru A|year=1998|title=The Influence of Whole Body Vibration on Jumping Performance|url=http://amplitudevibration.com/images/uploads/Influence_of_WBV_on_Jumping_Height.pdf|journal=Biology of Sport|volume=15|issue=3|pages=157–164|name-list-format=vanc}}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> In 1996 the first Galileo vibrating dumbbell patent was filed.<ref name="Bosco99a">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bosco C, Cardinale M, Tsarpela O | title = Influence of vibration on mechanical power and electromyogram activity in human arm flexor muscles | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology and Occupational Physiology | volume = 79 | issue = 4 | pages = 306–11 | date = March 1999 | pmid = 10090628 | doi = 10.1007/s004210050512 }}</ref>
===Training effects=== According to [[Mayo Clinic]], whole body vibration can offer some fitness and health benefits, but it is not clear if it is as beneficial as regular physical exercise.<ref name=mayo/> A review in 2014 came to the conclusion that there is little and inconsistent evidence that acute and/or chronic whole body vibration could improve the performance of competitive and/or elite athletes.<ref name=eurjhm/>
[[Cochrane review]]s have concluded that there is insufficient evidence of effect of whole body vibration training on functional performance of people with [[neurodegenerative disease]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cochrane.org/CD009097/MOVEMENT_whole-body-vibration-platform-training-in-patients-with-neurodegenerative-diseases|title=Whole-body vibration platform training in patients with neurodegenerative diseases|website=[[Cochrane collaboration]]|date=2012-02-15|author=Sitjà Rabert M, Rigau Comas D, Fort Vanmeerhaeghe A, Santoyo Medina C, Roqué i Figuls M, Romero-Rodríguez D, Bonfill Cosp}}</ref> or in disease-related problems in people with [[fibromyalgia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cochrane.org/CD011755/MUSKEL_whole-body-vibration-training-adults-fibromyalgia|title=Whole body vibration training for adults with fibromyalgia|website=[[Cochrane collaboration]]|date=2017-09-26|author=Bidonde J, Busch AJ, van der Spuy I, Tupper S, Kim SY, Boden C}}</ref>
===Vibrating platform types===
Vibrating platforms fall into different, distinct categories. The type of platform used is a moderator of the effect and result of the training or therapy performed (''Marin PJ, Rhea MR, 2010''<ref name="marin2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Marín PJ, Rhea MR | title = Effects of vibration training on muscle power: a meta-analysis | journal = Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research | volume = 24 | issue = 3 | pages = 871–8 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 20145554 | doi = 10.1519/JSC.0b013e3181c7c6f0 }}</ref>). Main categories of machine types are: # High Energy Lineal, found mostly in commercial vibration training studios and gyms. The vibration direction is lineal/upward # Premium Speed Pivotal, (teeter-totter movement) used for physiotherapy work at lower speeds and exercise workouts at “premium” speed, up to 30 Hz. Both commercial and home units are available. # Medium Energy Lineal, the majority of lineal platforms produced. These are usually made of plastic; some have 3-D vibration which is low quality. # Low Speed Pivotal units. Other machine types are low Energy/Low amplitude lineal and Low energy/High amplitude lineal.
Concerning the z-movements, two main types of system can be distinguished (''Marin PJ et al. 2010'',<ref name="marin2010"/> ''Rittweger 2010'',<ref name="Rittweger10">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rittweger J | title = Vibration as an exercise modality: how it may work, and what its potential might be | journal = European Journal of Applied Physiology | volume = 108 | issue = 5 | pages = 877–904 | date = March 2010 | pmid = 20012646 | doi = 10.1007/s00421-009-1303-3 }}</ref> ''Rauch 2010''<ref name="Rauch10">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rauch F, Sievanen H, Boonen S, Cardinale M, Degens H, Felsenberg D, Roth J, Schoenau E, Verschueren S, Rittweger J | title = Reporting whole-body vibration intervention studies: recommendations of the International Society of Musculoskeletal and Neuronal Interactions | journal = Journal of Musculoskeletal & Neuronal Interactions | volume = 10 | issue = 3 | pages = 193–8 | date = September 2010 | pmid = 20811143 | author11 = International Society of Musculoskeletal Neuronal Interactions }}</ref>) : * Side alternating (pivotal) systems, operating like a see-saw and hence mimicking the human gait where one foot is always moving upwards and the other one downwards, and * Linear systems where the whole platform is mainly doing the same motion, respectively: both feet are moved upwards or downwards at the same time. Systems with side alternation usually have a larger amplitude of oscillation and a frequency range of about 5 Hz to 40 Hz. Linear/upright systems have lower amplitudes but higher frequencies in the range of 20 Hz to 50 Hz. Despite the larger amplitudes of side-alternating systems, the vibration (acceleration) transmitted to the head is significantly smaller than in non side-alternating systems (''Abercromby et al. 2007''<ref name="Abercromby07b"/>) while at the same time muscle activation even at identical vibration parameters are increased in pivotal systems.<ref name="Ritzmann13">Ritzmann R, Gollhofer A, Kramer A: ''The influence of vibration type, frequency, body position and additional load on the neuromuscular activity during whole body vibration.'', European Journal of Applied Physiology, (113):1-11, 2013; {{PMID|22538279}}</ref>
Mechanical stimulation generates acceleration forces acting on the body. These forces cause the muscles to lengthen, and this signal is received by the muscle spindle, a small organ in the muscle. This spindle transmits the signal through the [[central nervous system]] to the muscles involved (''Abercromby et al. 2007'',<ref name="Abercromby07b">{{cite journal | vauthors = Abercromby AF, Amonette WE, Layne CS, McFarlin BK, Hinman MR, Paloski WH | title = Vibration exposure and biodynamic responses during whole-body vibration training | journal = Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise | volume = 39 | issue = 10 | pages = 1794–800 | date = October 2007 | pmid = 17909407 | doi = 10.1249/mss.0b013e3181238a0f }}</ref> ''Burkhardt 2006''<ref name="Burkhardt06">Burkhardt A.: ''Vibrationstraining in der Physiotherapie - Wippen mit Wirkung'', Physiopraxis 9/06, s.22.25, 2006</ref>).
'''Power Plate''' is a brand of vibrating platform consisting of a vibrating base, which may vibrate up and down approximately {{convert|1|to|2|mm|thou}} (1/16") 25 to 50 times per second.<ref name="bautmans">{{cite journal| vauthors = Bautmans I, Van Hees E, Lemper JC, Mets T | title = The feasibility of Whole Body Vibration in institutionalised elderly persons and its influence on muscle performance, balance and mobility: a randomised controlled trial [ISRCTN62535013] | journal = BMC Geriatrics | volume = 5 | pages = 17 | date = December 2005 | pmid = 16372905 | pmc = 1368976 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2318-5-17 | url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2318/5/17}}</ref> The machine is large enough to accommodate a person in [[deep squat]]. Traditional exercises such as squats and push-ups can be done on the vibrating base.<ref>{{cite book | last = Heyward | first = Vivian H | name-list-format = vanc | title = Advanced fitness assessment and exercise prescription | publisher = Human Kinetics | year = 2006 | pages = 159 | isbn = 978-0-7360-5732-5 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4GpPGl-79HgC&pg=PA159&dq="power+plate"+vibration }}</ref>
'''Galileo''' (in the US up until 2014 also available as '''Vibraflex''') is a brand of vibration training platforms used as [[exercise equipment]] as well as for therapeutic use. It consists of a vibration platform which vibrates sinusoidal side alternating like a see-saw. Depending on the device size it oscillates with an amplitude of up to 6 mm (equivalent to a peak to peak distance of 12 mm) and a frequency of 5 Hz to 40 Hz (5 to 40 repetitions per second). Galileo is manufactured in Germany by the German company Novotec Medical GmbH. Since 2004 Galileo is also available as a medical device.
The base plate of Galileo vibration training devices is moving like a see-saw. This side alternating motion is supposed to mimic human gait in order to utilize nearly physiological motion patterns close to the side alternating human gait. The side alternation causes the hip to tilt which requires the contra lateral muscles of the back to be activated – while one leg is lifted the other drops.<ref name="Rittweger02">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rittweger J, Just K, Kautzsch K, Reeg P, Felsenberg D | title = Treatment of chronic lower back pain with lumbar extension and whole-body vibration exercise: a randomized controlled trial | journal = Spine | volume = 27 | issue = 17 | pages = 1829–34 | date = September 2002 | pmid = 12221343 | doi = 10.1097/00007632-200209010-00003 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.484.6691 }}</ref> Compared to vertically vibrating devices the side alternating motion results in very low acceleration acting on the centre of gravity of the upper body and the head.<ref name="Pel09">{{cite journal | vauthors = Pel JJ, Bagheri J, van Dam LM, van den Berg-Emons HJ, Horemans HL, Stam HJ, van der Steen J | title = Platform accelerations of three different whole-body vibration devices and the transmission of vertical vibrations to the lower limbs | journal = Medical Engineering & Physics | volume = 31 | issue = 8 | pages = 937–44 | date = October 2009 | pmid = 19523867 | doi = 10.1016/j.medengphy.2009.05.005 }}</ref><ref name="Abercromby07b"/><ref name="Spitzenpfeil06">{{cite journal | vauthors = Spitzenpfeil P, Stritzker M, Kirchbichler A, Tusker F, Hartmann U, Hartard H | year = 2006 | title = Mechanical impacts to the human body by different vibration training devices | url = | journal = Journal of Biomechanics | volume = 39 | issue = Suppl 1 | page = 196 | doi = 10.1016/S0021-9290(06)83707-3 }}</ref>
===Belts=== A '''vibrating belt machine''' (also '''Mueller belt machine''', '''belt massager''', or '''jiggler machine''') is an exercise machine that uses a vibrating belt, to be used around the [[waist]] or [[buttocks]].

Johnson | signeddate = December 15, 1967 | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Wholesome Meat Act''' (also called "Equal To" law) is a [[United States federal law]] enacted in 1967 amending the [[Federal Meat Inspection Act]] which established a statute for federal meat inspection programs. It requires that states have inspection programs "equal to" that of the federal government which are administered by the [[Food Safety and Inspection Service]] (FSIS) of the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] (USDA).
The H.R. 12144 [[Bill (law)|legislation]] was passed by the 90th United States Congressional session and enacted into law by the [[Presidency of Lyndon B. Johnson|36th President of the United States]] Lyndon Johnson on December 15, 1967.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=28607 |title = Lyndon B. Johnson: "Remarks Upon Signing Bill Amending the Meat Inspection Act.," December 15, 1967 |author1= Gerhard Peters |author2 = John T. Woolley |publisher = University of California - Santa Barbara |work = The American}}</ref>
